greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Count of indices x in [0,n] that satisfy the equation A000120(x) + A000120(n-x) = A000120(n) + 2.
comment: For every solution x, binomial(n,x) is 4 times an odd integer.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
L. Spiegelhofer, M. Wallner, Divisibility of binomial coefficients by powers of two, arXiv:1710.10884
example: For n=8, there are a(8)=2 solutions, namely x=2 and x=6.
For n=9, there are a(9)=4 solutions, namely x=2, 3, 6 and 7.
maple: A163577 := proc(n) local a,x ; a := 0 ; for x from 0 to n do if A000120(x)+A000120(n-x) = A000120(n)+2 then a := a+1; fi; od: a; end:
mathematica: a120[n_] := DigitCount[n, 2, 1]; a[n_] := Count[Range[0, n], x_ /; a120[x] + a120[n-x] == a120[n]+2]; Array[a, 90, 0] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 10 2017 *)
xref: A001316 and A163000 count binomial coefficients with 2-adic valuation 0 and 1. A275012 gives a measure of complexity of these sequences. - _Eric Rowland_, Mar 15 2017
results.author: _Vladimir Shevelev_, Jul 31 2009
ext: Extended beyond a(22), examples added by _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 08 2009
